rOMTUx-y5.memHandModelNotes: ****Width of stream would be a good layer for predicting this species occurence in rivers and streams (if categorized would include in medium and large streams/rivers). Flow Accumulation may be a good predictor for this species since it needs wider, moving rivers and streams.  There is no literature documenting this species as using shallow waters only however, this species was formerly considered G. pseudogeographica which is restricted to more shallow waters. So applied and INTO Buffer. Amy Silvano 7jul05

habitat_description:
Populations of this species occur in the Mississippi and St. Croix river systems in Minnesota and Wisconsin (Oldfield and Moriarty 1994; Vogt 1981). Also. South of the Mississippi River basin through Louisiana and eastern Kansas. Disjunct populations are found in central Kansas, Oklahoma (Lake Texoma), Indiana, Ohio, and Kentucky (Natureserve.org; Vogt 1981). Subspecies Sabinensis occupies the Sabine drainage of Louisiana and Texas (Ernst et al. 1994; Vogt 1993; Vogt 1995).

This species is described as a benthic species known to burrow in or using soil. Primary habitats include big rivers, creeks, and low gradient streams. Also, temporary pools and other riparian situations. Not very common, but also found on sand dunes (Natureserve.org). Nesting occurs in beaches and sandbars within 100 meters of permanent water sources (Vogt 1981). Hibernation sites may be under rocks, wing dams, or underwater (Natureserve.org; Vogt 1981).

In Kansas, this species is reported to be abundant in rivers characterized by submerged aquatic vegetation (Fuselier and Edds 1994).

Not any specific cover species, but implied to have strong relationships with dense vegetation found in riparian zones.
